original: Post-Default Rate means, in respect of any principal of any Loan, the rate otherwise applicable plus an additional four percent (4.0%) per annum and with respect to any other Obligation, a rate per annum equal to the Base Rate as in effect from time to time plus the Applicable Margin for Base Rate Loans plus four percent (4.0%).
preferred:
1. If you borrow money, the interest rate might increase by 4% each year. This is called the Post-Default Rate.
    2. If you don't pay back the loan, the Administrative Agent can change the interest rate. Their decision is final unless there's a big mistake.
    3. The interest rate for many financial products is based on the LIBOR rate.
    4. Mandatorily Redeemable Stock is a type of share that can be bought back under certain conditions. Occupancy Rate, for a building, is the percentage of rented space.
not-preferred:
When you borrow money, you pay more interest on top of what's already there. This extra interest is four percent more than the regular interest. For example, if you have a loan with regular interest, and the regular interest is five percent, the extra interest is five percent plus four percent. That makes the total interest nine percent.


    Another example would be for other loans like credit cards, the interest rate is the base rate, which is the regular interest rate. The base rate is then four percent higher, plus the extra margin, which is like a little extra fee. So the total interest is the base rate plus the extra margin, plus four percent. This makes the total interest nine percent again.


    We will use the rate of nine percent for all our loans. This is the post-default rate, which is the regular interest plus the extra four percent. We will apply this rate to all our loans and other obligations, like credit cards, to make sure everyone pays the same amount of interest.

preferred: What is a financial institution? A financial institution is a bank or a company that helps people save and borrow money. In some countries, like the ones in Europe, there are special rules to help keep them safe. These rules are called the Bail-In Legislation Schedule. The European Union made a special rule called the EU-EEA Financial Institution Regulation. This rule helps decide what happens when a bank or company gets into trouble. It's like a safety net that helps keep everyone safe. The EU-EEA Financial Institution Regulation is like a big team that works together to help keep the banks and companies safe. It's made up of many rules that help decide what happens when a bank or company gets into trouble.

    2. This EEA Financial Institution can be a parent, child, or related bank or investment firm in an EEA country.

    Note: EEA stands for European Economic Area, which includes countries in the European Union and some other European countries.
    Credit institution refers to a bank, while investment firm refers to a company that trades on behalf of clients in financial instruments like shares and bonds.
    EEA Resolution Authority is the authority that supervises these institutions in an EEA country.

    4. The new lender and the old lender will agree on the exact amount.

The other lenders can still work on the loan, but the lender that stopped working has to sell their part of the loan to another lender for the amount they owe, plus extra fees. The other lender will buy it from the one that stopped working.

original: The Borrower shall not, and shall not permit any other Loan Party or any other Subsidiary (other than an Excluded Subsidiary) to, create or otherwise cause or suffer to exist or become effective any consensual encumbrance or restriction of any kind on the ability of any Subsidiary to: (a) pay dividends or make any other distribution on any of such Subsidiarys capital stock or other equity interests owned by the Borrower or any Subsidiary; (b) pay any Indebtedness owed to the Borrower or any Subsidiary; (c) make loans or advances to the Borrower or any Subsidiary; or (d) transfer any of its property or assets to the Borrower or any Subsidiary; other than (i) with respect to clauses (a) through (d), those encumbrances or restrictions contained in any Loan Document or in any other agreement (A) evidencing Unsecured Indebtedness that the Borrower, any other Loan Party or any other Subsidiary may create, incur, assume or permit or suffer to exist under this Agreement and (B) containing encumbrances and restrictions imposed in connection with such Unsecured Indebtedness that are either substantially similar to, or less restrictive than, such encumbrances and restrictions set forth in the Loan Documents, (ii) with respect to clause (d), customary provisions restricting assignment of any agreement entered into by the Borrower, any other Loan Party or any Subsidiary in the ordinary course of business and (iii) with respect to clauses (a) through (d), in the case of a Subsidiary that is not a Wholly Owned Subsidiary, limitations arising after the date hereof to the effect that any such dividends, distributions, loans, advances or transfers of property must be on fair and reasonable terms and on an arms length basis.
preferred:
Here's what the Borrower (the person or company lending money) can't do:
    - Can't let others put a stop on the money the company has, like stopping it from paying dividends (sharing profits) or paying back loans.
    - Can't let others stop the company from paying back the money it owes the Borrower.
    - Can't let others give the company money to pay the Borrower back.
    - Can't let others sell the company's stuff to the Borrower.
    But, there are some special rules:
    - If the company owes money to the Borrower, it can still put limits on how much money it can share with others (like not letting others take its profits).
    - The company can still make loans to the Borrower (like lending the Borrower its own money).
    - The company can still sell its stuff to the Borrower (but the price has to be fair and not too good for the company).
    Note: The company can't let others take over its business, but that's just a normal rule in business.
not-preferred:
1. The Borrower can't stop others from changing rules that affect how Subsidiaries can:
       a. Give money to the Borrower or other Subsidiaries as dividends or other payments.
       b. Pay back money they owe to the Borrower or other Subsidiaries.
       c. Lend or give money to the Borrower or other Subsidiaries.
       d. Give property or assets to the Borrower or other Subsidiaries, except:
           i. If the rules are in a loan agreement or other contract.
           ii. If it's normal business practice to limit who can change agreements.
           iii. If the Subsidiary isn't fully owned by the Borrower, the rules can be changed as long as it's fair and reasonable.

preferred:
The company is not responsible for any mistakes with the money transfer. 
    The person in charge of the money transfer (the Administrative Agent) is the only one allowed to make decisions about the money. 
    The Administrative Agent can do things on its own, like protect its own money. 
    The Administrative Agent can also help the other people who lent the money (the Lenders). 
    If the Administrative Agent can't do its job, then the people who lent the money (the Lenders) can help. 
    The Lenders can also help each other if they need to. 
    The company is not responsible for mistakes that happen after the Administrative Agent makes a decision. 
    If the Administrative Agent can't do its job, then the Lenders can make their own decisions. 
    The Lenders can also help each other if they need to.

If needed, the bank can change some or all of its debt into shares or other ownership things. These shares can be given to the bank instead of paying back the debt. This can happen with an EEA Financial Institution, its parent company, or a special bank called a bridge institution. This is allowed under this agreement or any other loan document.

not-preferred: In a big company, they can change the rules so that they are not responsible for paying a lot of money. Instead, they can give the company some shares or special papers that say they own part of the company. The company will accept these shares instead of getting the money. This is called a "conversion of liability". It's like swapping one thing for another thing, so they can avoid paying the money.

original: Section 9\. Effect; Ratification. Except as expressly herein amended, the terms and conditions of the Credit Agreement and the other Loan Documents remain in full force and effect. Nothing in this Amendment shall limit, impair or constitute a waiver of the rights, powers or remedies available to the Administrative Agent or the Lenders under the Credit Agreement or any other Loan Document.
